Rationale
This module is being created in order to facilitate XJTLU Pharmaceutical Sciences MRes Students to visit Liverpool to undertake their project. The overall module APH425 will continue to be managed at XJTLU, but the students will join Liverpool to use our facilities and gain additional benefits of studying abroad.

Admin

Marked for Rollover

Replace Future Instances

Replace Instances with Code
BIOS799
Notes
This is a new module designed for the students who enrol for MRes in Pharmaceutical Sciences in the XJTLU. This new module will be optional for year 2 for XJTLU students to undertake their research project in the University of Liverpool. XJTLU students who select this module will arrive in UoL to undertake their research project in UoL laboratories under the supervision of a UoL academic supervisor. Following their laboratory studies in the UoL, students will return to the XJTLU campus end of April for write-up of the dissertation and assessments will be undertaken at XJTLU.

Overview

Overview
The MRes in Pharmaceutical Sciences APH425 Study Abroad (Liverpool) module aims to provide XJTLU students with high level research training within the Institute of Systems, Molecular and Integrative Medicine (ISMIB) Schools and research departments contributing to the MRes in Pharmaceutical Sciences programme run by XJTLU. This module will be an optional module available to Y2 students undertaking the MRes in Pharmaceutical Sciences programme at the XJTLU and enable them to undertake their research project in the University of Liverpool. The module represents 120 credits, but is classed as 0 for UoL purposes because this is assessed by XJTLU.

Our aim is to develop research knowledge, skills and attributes including confidence and expertise, to contribute to the pursuit of further study or undertake roles in academia, the health sector and industry/education/service sectors in general. The module is suitable for bioscience graduates, and science graduates interested in training in biomedical sciences.

Students will join a UoL research group and take advantage of relevant first-class facilities and an active research environment at the University of Liverpool. This module is designed to provide a clear progression of research education.

Students will join Liverpool for a proportion of the APH425 module, a 120-credit (XJTLU) module that gives authentic and hands-on research experience. Students focus on a dedicated research project, which includes preparing a preliminary report; preparing a project plan and undertaking original research using experimental/data handling techniques learned; writing up a dissertation in the style of a paper in a scientific journal and preparing an oral presentation to discuss their project, together with continual assessment of the student’s performance (Hallmarks of Liverpool Curriculum Framework). The teaching approach relies upon research-led and enquiry-based learning with authentic assessments in the form of a preliminary project proposal, oral presentation, scientific report, and continual assessment of the student’s performance (Hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

The teaching delivery is based on the research supervisor model used for postgraduate research degrees. Students will be provided with training in relevant research techniques required for their own project, but will subsequently develop the ability to work independently on their own project. Generic guidance on preparation of the written report and oral presentation will be given and supplemented by project-specific guidance provided by the project supervisor. Write-up of the dissertation will take place following the return of students to the XJTLU campus and the assessment of the module is undertaken at XJTLU via the preliminary project proposal, oral presentation and project report along with continual assessment of the student's performance.

Students will normally choose their project from a list provided on receipt of their offer, but it is possible for them to work with the Module Organiser to find a potential supervisor and develop a project more aligned to their own interests if a suitable project has not been provided. Projects address research areas that reflect the strengths of ISMIB and covers a wide range of formats including (but not limited to) bioinformatics, clinical studies, animal studies, cell and tissue culture, systematic reviews and meta-analyses, computer modelling. The supervisor is responsible for supporting the development of the technical and analytical skills needed for the project. Direction of the project should be primarily student-led enquiry with support from the supervisor and their team, where appropriate. The purpose of this approach is to facilitate the development of problem- solving skills; critical thinking; scientific creativity; an ability to apply appropriate experimental design and analysis and the skills to communicate findings and ideas to a wide audience. This approach is consistent with the Liverpool Hallmarks of research-connected teaching and active learning as set out in the Liverpool Curriculum Framework.
Educational Aims
1.To provide students with an opportunity to conduct in-depth, cutting-edge, independent research on a defined topic under supervision of a qualified member of academic staff within an active, first-class research environment.

2.To give students a holistic training in practical research and make an original and significant contribution to knowledge in the specific field of study.

3.To enable students to gain a comprehensive understanding of the techniques applicable to research or advanced scholarship.

4.To facilitate the developments of project management skills, report writing skills, presentation skills, time management skills for research or investigative work in their professional careers.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Not Required as it is not marketed outside (only limited to XJTLU)
Outline Syllabus
All students are provided with a list of research projects which are related to the research currently undertaken by ISMIB academic staff. Students are free to make their choice according to their specific needs or interest.

In general, students are required to perform the following tasks within this module:

• Gain knowledge of lab safety and the principles of research ethics
• Complete a risk assessment for their research project
• Perform literature survey of their chosen research area and keep information updated
• Submit a literature survey report
• Submit a proposed project plan detailing the research activities (to be approved by supervisor)
• Perform research activity according to the agreed plan
• Produce a poster to present their research project.
• Perform oral presentation of their poster
• Submit a progress research reports at the end of Semester 2
• Deliver a power point presentation of research outcome
• Submit a final thesis
Teaching and Learning Methods
This module involves tutorials to help students gain knowledge of lab safety, principles of research ethics, literature survey, presentation, report writing, project planning, etc. Students are required to attend departmental seminars to increase their general knowledge. Specific technical training will be given by supervisor and technical supporting staffs. We will also provide pastoral support to the students during their time in Liverpool.

Students have to choose a specified research project and submit a preliminary report, describing the relevant background information, the hypothesis to be tested (where relevant), a plan of work and an anticipated timetable.

Students will undertake the research projects in two semesters. The results arising from the research will be subsequently reported by oral presentation and a research paper/dissertation. Timely, relevant and specific, constructive and actionable feedback will be provided to students in-class, on-paper and/or in-person on for each assignment.

The students on the programme come from a wide background. During their time spent in Liverpool, discussion between students and their research colleagues, from these diverse backgrounds affords the students a rich opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this multinational community fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their internationalised perspective (Global citizenship, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching and learning may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
All students plan a dedicated empirical research project, the content of which is directed by the academic supervisor of the project.

The module is assessed by XJTLU via submission of a preliminary literature survey report and project plan, an oral presentation to peers and academic members, submission of dissertation and continual assessment (See detailed assessment plan given under 'Assessments' tab). Written assessments are submitted and marked online for all students including a draft formative opportunity.
The continual assessment element will assess the student’s conduct and performance throughout the project and will be conducted by the Liverpool Supervisor.

The preliminary project report will not be marked anonymously as it will need to be marked by the UoL supervisor, an expert on the research topic and so the student will be easily identified. The reports reflect real-life scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark, Liverpool Curriculum Framework). The preliminary report will be a literature survey of the research area suggested, critical analysis of the literature, and would include a hypothesis. The preliminary report will also support the development of communication skills, data analysis and discussion of findings in relation to the field of research. The dissertation will be marked by 2 markers (one from UoL [supervisor] and the other from XJTLU). Oral presentations will be carried out in a hybrid format and will be marked by 3-4 markers.

The oral presentation reflects real-life situations (authentic assessment hallmark, Liverpool Curriculum Framework) for a research scientist and will be assessed by the panel on scientific correctness, presentation skills, time management and ability to answer questions. The assessments aim to support scientific and lay communication skills development, reflection on the project and self-confidence. In order to minimise the impact of air travel on climate change many conferences, poster and oral presentations are now taking place online or in a hybrid model e.g. with invited international attendees presenting via live video communication links. We will ensure that a hybrid model is possible with the option to change to completely online when necessary.

Re-sits are only available for the dissertation (resubmission) and not for the other components (see details below).

The break-down of the summative coursework assessments are as follows:

1)Literature Survey and project plan (15% final mark), testing LO’s 1, 2, and 3 with no resit.

2)Log Book (5% final mark), testing LO 4, with no resit.

3)Oral Presentation (15% final mark), testing LO’s 1, 2, and 5 with no resit.

4)Dissertation (65% final mark), testing LO’s 1, 2, 3, 4, and 6 with a resit opportunity.

Marks for components where no resit opportunities are offered will be carried forward, whether or not they are passed or failed, and will be calculated, with the same weighting, in the final module mark.
The dissertation resit is an independent assessment covering the same learning outcomes, in the same assessment type and bearing the same weighting with the original assessment.


Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcomeDeliveries 
 LO1 Critically evaluate relevant scientific literature and relate and combine it with the arguments, criteria, justifications and/or discussions of the project 
 LO2 Plan a piece of scientific research to formulate, evaluate or criticise a hypothesis and propose and formulate a set of experiments to test, challenge or defend this hypothesis, within a specified timeframe. 
 LO3 Consider, formulate and apply research ethics and health and safety regulations to prioritize, arrange and organize research work 
 LO4 Work independently in the lab with the essential technical skills acquired in a professional manner; maintaining an accurate and authentic record of methods and experimental findings 
 LO5 Effectively communicate and present their work to a scientific audience in the form of an oral and poster presentations 
 LO6 Write a final project report in the format of a dissertation to evaluate, contrast and discuss, the experimental outcomes of the research project and their scientific implications and significance 
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcomeDeliveries 
 S1 Literacy ability to produce clear, structured written work and oral literacy - including listening and questioning 
 S2 Problem solving/ critical thinking/ creativity analysing facts and situations and applying creative thinking to develop appropriate solutions. 
 S3 Communication, listening and questioning respecting others, contributing to discussions, influencing, presentations. 
 S4 Self-management readiness to accept responsibility (i.e. leadership), flexibility, resilience, self-starting, initiative, integrity, willingness to take risks, appropriate assertiveness, time management, readiness to improve own performance based on feedback/reflective learning. 
 S5 Plan research within ethical, health and safety, and research governance frameworks. 


Overview

Requirements Overview
Companion study abroad research project module to XJTLU MRes Pharmaceutical Sciences module (APH425).

Students will complete their lab work in Liverpool and return to china to complete their write up. The project will be formally assessed by XJTLU.

• Gain knowledge of lab safety and the principles of research ethics
• Complete a risk assessment for their research project
• Perform literature survey of their chosen research area and keep information updated
• Submit a literature survey report
• Submit a proposed project plan detailing the research activities (to be approved by supervisor)
• Perform research activity according to the agreed plan
• Produce a poster to present their research project.
• Perform oral presentation of their poster
• Submit a progress research reports at the end of Semester 2
• Deliver a power point presentation of research outcome
• Submit a final thesis
Teaching and Learning Methods
This module involves tutorials to help students gain knowledge of lab safety, principles of research ethics, literature survey, presentation, report writing, project planning, etc. Students are required to attend departmental seminars to increase their general knowledge. Specific technical training will be given by supervisor and technical supporting staffs. We will also provide pastoral support to the students during their time in Liverpool.

Students have to choose a specified research project and submit a preliminary report, describing the relevant background information, the hypothesis to be tested (where relevant), a plan of work and an anticipated timetable.

Students will undertake the research projects in two semesters. The results arising from the research will be subsequently reported by oral presentation and a research paper/dissertation. Timely, relevant and specific, constructive and actionable feedback will be provided to students in-class, on-paper and/or in-person on for each assignment.

The students on the programme come from a wide background. During their time spent in Liverpool, discussion between students and their research colleagues, from these diverse backgrounds affords the students a rich opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this multinational community fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their internationalised perspective (Global citizenship, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching and learning may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
All students plan a dedicated empirical research project, the content of which is directed by the academic supervisor of the project.

The module is assessed by XJTLU via submission of a preliminary literature survey report and project plan, an oral presentation to peers and academic members, submission of dissertation and continual assessment (See detailed assessment plan given under 'Assessments' tab). Written assessments are submitted and marked online for all students including a draft formative opportunity.
The continual assessment element will assess the student’s conduct and performance throughout the project and will be conducted by the Liverpool Supervisor.

The preliminary project report will not be marked anonymously as it will need to be marked by the UoL supervisor, an expert on the research topic and so the student will be easily identified. The reports reflect real-life scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark, Liverpool Curriculum Framework). The preliminary report will be a literature survey of the research area suggested, critical analysis of the literature, and would include a hypothesis. The preliminary report will also support the development of communication skills, data analysis and discussion of findings in relation to the field of research. The dissertation will be marked by 2 markers (one from UoL [supervisor] and the other from XJTLU). Oral presentations will be carried out in a hybrid format and will be marked by 3-4 markers.

The oral presentation reflects real-life situations (authentic assessment hallmark, Liverpool Curriculum Framework) for a research scientist and will be assessed by the panel on scientific correctness, presentation skills, time management and ability to answer questions. The assessments aim to support scientific and lay communication skills development, reflection on the project and self-confidence. In order to minimise the impact of air travel on climate change many conferences, poster and oral presentations are now taking place online or in a hybrid model e.g. with invited international attendees presenting via live video communication links. We will ensure that a hybrid model is possible with the option to change to completely online when necessary.

Re-sits are only available for the dissertation (resubmission) and not for the other components (see details below).

The break-down of the summative coursework assessments are as follows:

1)Literature Survey and project plan (15% final mark), testing LO’s 1, 2, and 3 with no resit.

2)Log Book (5% final mark), testing LO 4, with no resit.

3)Oral Presentation (15% final mark), testing LO’s 1, 2, and 5 with no resit.

4)Dissertation (65% final mark), testing LO’s 1, 2, 3, 4, and 6 with a resit opportunity.

Marks for components where no resit opportunities are offered will be carried forward, whether or not they are passed or failed, and will be calculated, with the same weighting, in the final module mark.
The dissertation resit is an independent assessment covering the same learning outcomes, in the same assessment type and bearing the same weighting with the original assessment.


Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcomeDeliveries 
 LO1 Critically evaluate relevant scientific literature and relate and combine it with the arguments, criteria, justifications and/or discussions of the project 
 LO2 Plan a piece of scientific research to formulate, evaluate or criticise a hypothesis and propose and formulate a set of experiments to test, challenge or defend this hypothesis, within a specified timeframe. 
 LO3 Consider, formulate and apply research ethics and health and safety regulations to prioritize, arrange and organize research work 
 LO4 Work independently in the lab with the essential technical skills acquired in a professional manner; maintaining an accurate and authentic record of methods and experimental findings 
 LO5 Effectively communicate and present their work to a scientific audience in the form of an oral and poster presentations 
 LO6 Write a final project report in the format of a dissertation to evaluate, contrast and discuss, the experimental outcomes of the research project and their scientific implications and significance 
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcomeDeliveries 
 S1 Literacy ability to produce clear, structured written work and oral literacy - including listening and questioning 
 S2 Problem solving/ critical thinking/ creativity analysing facts and situations and applying creative thinking to develop appropriate solutions. 
 S3 Communication, listening and questioning respecting others, contributing to discussions, influencing, presentations. 
 S4 Self-management readiness to accept responsibility (i.e. leadership), flexibility, resilience, self-starting, initiative, integrity, willingness to take risks, appropriate assertiveness, time management, readiness to improve own performance based on feedback/reflective learning. 
 S5 Plan research within ethical, health and safety, and research governance frameworks. 


Overview

Requirements Overview
Companion study abroad research project module to XJTLU MRes Pharmaceutical Sciences module (APH425).

Students will complete their lab work in Liverpool and return to china to complete their write up. The project will be formally assessed by XJTLU.

Rationale
This module is being created in order to facilitate XJTLU Pharmaceutical Sciences MRes Students to visit Liverpool to undertake their project. The overall module APH425 will continue to be managed at XJTLU, but the students will join Liverpool to use our facilities and gain additional benefits of studying abroad.

Admin

Marked for Rollover
No
Replace Future Instances
No
Replace Instances with Code
BIOS799
Notes
This is a new module designed for the students who enrol for MRes in Pharmaceutical Sciences in the XJTLU. This new module will be optional for year 2 for XJTLU students to undertake their research project in the University of Liverpool. XJTLU students who select this module will arrive in UoL to undertake their research project in UoL laboratories under the supervision of a UoL academic supervisor. Following their laboratory studies in the UoL, students will return to the XJTLU campus end of April for write-up of the dissertation and assessments will be undertaken at XJTLU.

Overview

Overview
The MRes in Pharmaceutical Sciences APH425 Study Abroad (Liverpool) module aims to provide XJTLU students with high level research training within the Institute of Systems, Molecular and Integrative Medicine (ISMIB) Schools and research departments contributing to the MRes in Pharmaceutical Sciences programme run by XJTLU. This module will be an optional module available to Y2 students undertaking the MRes in Pharmaceutical Sciences programme at the XJTLU and enable them to undertake their research project in the University of Liverpool. The module represents 120 credits, but is classed as 0 for UoL purposes because this is assessed by XJTLU.

Our aim is to develop research knowledge, skills and attributes including confidence and expertise, to contribute to the pursuit of further study or undertake roles in academia, the health sector and industry/education/service sectors in general. The module is suitable for bioscience graduates, and science graduates interested in training in biomedical sciences.

Students will join a UoL research group and take advantage of relevant first-class facilities and an active research environment at the University of Liverpool. This module is designed to provide a clear progression of research education.

Students will join Liverpool for a proportion of the APH425 module, a 120-credit (XJTLU) module that gives authentic and hands-on research experience. Students focus on a dedicated research project, which includes preparing a preliminary report; preparing a project plan and undertaking original research using experimental/data handling techniques learned; writing up a dissertation in the style of a paper in a scientific journal and preparing an oral presentation to discuss their project, together with continual assessment of the student’s performance (Hallmarks of Liverpool Curriculum Framework). The teaching approach relies upon research-led and enquiry-based learning with authentic assessments in the form of a preliminary project proposal, oral presentation, scientific report, and continual assessment of the student’s performance (Hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

The teaching delivery is based on the research supervisor model used for postgraduate research degrees. Students will be provided with training in relevant research techniques required for their own project, but will subsequently develop the ability to work independently on their own project. Generic guidance on preparation of the written report and oral presentation will be given and supplemented by project-specific guidance provided by the project supervisor. Write-up of the dissertation will take place following the return of students to the XJTLU campus and the assessment of the module is undertaken at XJTLU via the preliminary project proposal, oral presentation and project report along with continual assessment of the student's performance.

Students will normally choose their project from a list provided on receipt of their offer, but it is possible for them to work with the Module Organiser to find a potential supervisor and develop a project more aligned to their own interests if a suitable project has not been provided. Projects address research areas that reflect the strengths of ISMIB and covers a wide range of formats including (but not limited to) bioinformatics, clinical studies, animal studies, cell and tissue culture, systematic reviews and meta-analyses, computer modelling. The supervisor is responsible for supporting the development of the technical and analytical skills needed for the project. Direction of the project should be primarily student-led enquiry with support from the supervisor and their team, where appropriate. The purpose of this approach is to facilitate the development of problem- solving skills; critical thinking; scientific creativity; an ability to apply appropriate experimental design and analysis and the skills to communicate findings and ideas to a wide audience. This approach is consistent with the Liverpool Hallmarks of research-connected teaching and active learning as set out in the Liverpool Curriculum Framework.
Educational Aims
1.To provide students with an opportunity to conduct in-depth, cutting-edge, independent research on a defined topic under supervision of a qualified member of academic staff within an active, first-class research environment.

2.To give students a holistic training in practical research and make an original and significant contribution to knowledge in the specific field of study.

3.To enable students to gain a comprehensive understanding of the techniques applicable to research or advanced scholarship.

4.To facilitate the developments of project management skills, report writing skills, presentation skills, time management skills for research or investigative work in their professional careers.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Not Required as it is not marketed outside (only limited to XJTLU)
Outline Syllabus
All students are provided with a list of research projects which are related to the research currently undertaken by ISMIB academic staff. Students are free to make their choice according to their specific needs or interest.

In general, students are required to perform the following tasks within this module:

• Gain knowledge of lab safety and the principles of research ethics
• Complete a risk assessment for their research project
• Perform literature survey of their chosen research area and keep information updated
• Submit a literature survey report
• Submit a proposed project plan detailing the research activities (to be approved by supervisor)
• Perform research activity according to the agreed plan
• Produce a poster to present their research project.
• Perform oral presentation of their poster
• Submit a progress research reports at the end of Semester 2
• Deliver a power point presentation of research outcome
• Submit a final thesis
Teaching and Learning Methods
This module involves tutorials to help students gain knowledge of lab safety, principles of research ethics, literature survey, presentation, report writing, project planning, etc. Students are required to attend departmental seminars to increase their general knowledge. Specific technical training will be given by supervisor and technical supporting staffs. We will also provide pastoral support to the students during their time in Liverpool.

Students have to choose a specified research project and submit a preliminary report, describing the relevant background information, the hypothesis to be tested (where relevant), a plan of work and an anticipated timetable.

Students will undertake the research projects in two semesters. The results arising from the research will be subsequently reported by oral presentation and a research paper/dissertation. Timely, relevant and specific, constructive and actionable feedback will be provided to students in-class, on-paper and/or in-person on for each assignment.

The students on the programme come from a wide background. During their time spent in Liverpool, discussion between students and their research colleagues, from these diverse backgrounds affords the students a rich opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this multinational community fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their internationalised perspective (Global citizenship, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching and learning may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
All students plan a dedicated empirical research project, the content of which is directed by the academic supervisor of the project.

The module is assessed by XJTLU via submission of a preliminary literature survey report and project plan, an oral presentation to peers and academic members, submission of dissertation and continual assessment (See detailed assessment plan given under 'Assessments' tab). Written assessments are submitted and marked online for all students including a draft formative opportunity.
The continual assessment element will assess the student’s conduct and performance throughout the project and will be conducted by the Liverpool Supervisor.

The preliminary project report will not be marked anonymously as it will need to be marked by the UoL supervisor, an expert on the research topic and so the student will be easily identified. The reports reflect real-life scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark, Liverpool Curriculum Framework). The preliminary report will be a literature survey of the research area suggested, critical analysis of the literature, and would include a hypothesis. The preliminary report will also support the development of communication skills, data analysis and discussion of findings in relation to the field of research. The dissertation will be marked by 2 markers (one from UoL [supervisor] and the other from XJTLU). Oral presentations will be carried out in a hybrid format and will be marked by 3-4 markers.

The oral presentation reflects real-life situations (authentic assessment hallmark, Liverpool Curriculum Framework) for a research scientist and will be assessed by the panel on scientific correctness, presentation skills, time management and ability to answer questions. The assessments aim to support scientific and lay communication skills development, reflection on the project and self-confidence. In order to minimise the impact of air travel on climate change many conferences, poster and oral presentations are now taking place online or in a hybrid model e.g. with invited international attendees presenting via live video communication links. We will ensure that a hybrid model is possible with the option to change to completely online when necessary.

Re-sits are only available for the dissertation (resubmission) and not for the other components (see details below).

The break-down of the summative coursework assessments are as follows:

1)Literature Survey and project plan (15% final mark), testing LO’s 1, 2, and 3 with no resit.

2)Log Book (5% final mark), testing LO 4, with no resit.

3)Oral Presentation (15% final mark), testing LO’s 1, 2, and 5 with no resit.

4)Dissertation (65% final mark), testing LO’s 1, 2, 3, 4, and 6 with a resit opportunity.

Marks for components where no resit opportunities are offered will be carried forward, whether or not they are passed or failed, and will be calculated, with the same weighting, in the final module mark.
The dissertation resit is an independent assessment covering the same learning outcomes, in the same assessment type and bearing the same weighting with the original assessment.


Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

 S2 Problem solving/ critical thinking/ creativity analysing facts and situations and applying creative thinking to develop appropriate solutions. 
 S3 Communication, listening and questioning respecting others, contributing to discussions, influencing, presentations. 
 S4 Self-management readiness to accept responsibility (i.e. leadership), flexibility, resilience, self-starting, initiative, integrity, willingness to take risks, appropriate assertiveness, time management, readiness to improve own performance based on feedback/reflective learning. 
 S5 Plan research within ethical, health and safety, and research governance frameworks. 


Overview

Requirements Overview
Companion study abroad research project module to XJTLU MRes Pharmaceutical Sciences module (APH425).

Students will complete their lab work in Liverpool and return to china to complete their write up. The project will be formally assessed by XJTLU.

Rationale
This module is being created in order to facilitate XJTLU Pharmaceutical Sciences MRes Students to visit Liverpool to undertake their project. The overall module APH425 will continue to be managed at XJTLU, but the students will join Liverpool to use our facilities and gain additional benefits of studying abroad.

Admin

Marked for Rollover
No
Replace Future Instances
No
Replace Instances with Code
BIOS799
Notes
This is a new module designed for the students who enrol for MRes in Pharmaceutical Sciences in the XJTLU. This new module will be optional for year 2 for XJTLU students to undertake their research project in the University of Liverpool. XJTLU students who select this module will arrive in UoL to undertake their research project in UoL laboratories under the supervision of a UoL academic supervisor. Following their laboratory studies in the UoL, students will return to the XJTLU campus end of April for write-up of the dissertation and assessments will be undertaken at XJTLU.

Overview

Overview
The MRes in Pharmaceutical Sciences APH425 Study Abroad (Liverpool) module aims to provide XJTLU students with high level research training within the Institute of Systems, Molecular and Integrative Medicine (ISMIB) Schools and research departments contributing to the MRes in Pharmaceutical Sciences programme run by XJTLU. This module will be an optional module available to Y2 students undertaking the MRes in Pharmaceutical Sciences programme at the XJTLU and enable them to undertake their research project in the University of Liverpool. The module represents 120 credits, but is classed as 0 for UoL purposes because this is assessed by XJTLU.

Our aim is to develop research knowledge, skills and attributes including confidence and expertise, to contribute to the pursuit of further study or undertake roles in academia, the health sector and industry/education/service sectors in general. The module is suitable for bioscience graduates, and science graduates interested in training in biomedical sciences.

Students will join a UoL research group and take advantage of relevant first-class facilities and an active research environment at the University of Liverpool. This module is designed to provide a clear progression of research education.

Students will join Liverpool for a proportion of the APH425 module, a 120-credit (XJTLU) module that gives authentic and hands-on research experience. Students focus on a dedicated research project, which includes preparing a preliminary report; preparing a project plan and undertaking original research using experimental/data handling techniques learned; writing up a dissertation in the style of a paper in a scientific journal and preparing an oral presentation to discuss their project, together with continual assessment of the student’s performance (Hallmarks of Liverpool Curriculum Framework). The teaching approach relies upon research-led and enquiry-based learning with authentic assessments in the form of a preliminary project proposal, oral presentation, scientific report, and continual assessment of the student’s performance (Hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

The teaching delivery is based on the research supervisor model used for postgraduate research degrees. Students will be provided with training in relevant research techniques required for their own project, but will subsequently develop the ability to work independently on their own project. Generic guidance on preparation of the written report and oral presentation will be given and supplemented by project-specific guidance provided by the project supervisor. Write-up of the dissertation will take place following the return of students to the XJTLU campus and the assessment of the module is undertaken at XJTLU via the preliminary project proposal, oral presentation and project report along with continual assessment of the student's performance.

Students will normally choose their project from a list provided on receipt of their offer, but it is possible for them to work with the Module Organiser to find a potential supervisor and develop a project more aligned to their own interests if a suitable project has not been provided. Projects address research areas that reflect the strengths of ISMIB and covers a wide range of formats including (but not limited to) bioinformatics, clinical studies, animal studies, cell and tissue culture, systematic reviews and meta-analyses, computer modelling. The supervisor is responsible for supporting the development of the technical and analytical skills needed for the project. Direction of the project should be primarily student-led enquiry with support from the supervisor and their team, where appropriate. The purpose of this approach is to facilitate the development of problem- solving skills; critical thinking; scientific creativity; an ability to apply appropriate experimental design and analysis and the skills to communicate findings and ideas to a wide audience. This approach is consistent with the Liverpool Hallmarks of research-connected teaching and active learning as set out in the Liverpool Curriculum Framework.
Educational Aims
1.To provide students with an opportunity to conduct in-depth, cutting-edge, independent research on a defined topic under supervision of a qualified member of academic staff within an active, first-class research environment.

2.To give students a holistic training in practical research and make an original and significant contribution to knowledge in the specific field of study.

3.To enable students to gain a comprehensive understanding of the techniques applicable to research or advanced scholarship.

4.To facilitate the developments of project management skills, report writing skills, presentation skills, time management skills for research or investigative work in their professional careers.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Not Required as it is not marketed outside (only limited to XJTLU)
Outline Syllabus
All students are provided with a list of research projects which are related to the research currently undertaken by ISMIB academic staff. Students are free to make their choice according to their specific needs or interest.

In general, students are required to perform the following tasks within this module:

• Gain knowledge of lab safety and the principles of research ethics
• Complete a risk assessment for their research project
• Perform literature survey of their chosen research area and keep information updated
• Submit a literature survey report
• Submit a proposed project plan detailing the research activities (to be approved by supervisor)
• Perform research activity according to the agreed plan
• Produce a poster to present their research project.
• Perform oral presentation of their poster
• Submit a progress research reports at the end of Semester 2
• Deliver a power point presentation of research outcome
• Submit a final thesis
Teaching and Learning Methods
This module involves tutorials to help students gain knowledge of lab safety, principles of research ethics, literature survey, presentation, report writing, project planning, etc. Students are required to attend departmental seminars to increase their general knowledge. Specific technical training will be given by supervisor and technical supporting staffs. We will also provide pastoral support to the students during their time in Liverpool.

Students have to choose a specified research project and submit a preliminary report, describing the relevant background information, the hypothesis to be tested (where relevant), a plan of work and an anticipated timetable.

Students will undertake the research projects in two semesters. The results arising from the research will be subsequently reported by oral presentation and a research paper/dissertation. Timely, relevant and specific, constructive and actionable feedback will be provided to students in-class, on-paper and/or in-person on for each assignment.

The students on the programme come from a wide background. During their time spent in Liverpool, discussion between students and their research colleagues, from these diverse backgrounds affords the students a rich opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this multinational community fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their internationalised perspective (Global citizenship, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching and learning may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
All students plan a dedicated empirical research project, the content of which is directed by the academic supervisor of the project.

The module is assessed by XJTLU via submission of a preliminary literature survey report and project plan, an oral presentation to peers and academic members, submission of dissertation and continual assessment (See detailed assessment plan given under 'Assessments' tab). Written assessments are submitted and marked online for all students including a draft formative opportunity.
The continual assessment element will assess the student’s conduct and performance throughout the project and will be conducted by the Liverpool Supervisor.

The preliminary project report will not be marked anonymously as it will need to be marked by the UoL supervisor, an expert on the research topic and so the student will be easily identified. The reports reflect real-life scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark, Liverpool Curriculum Framework). The preliminary report will be a literature survey of the research area suggested, critical analysis of the literature, and would include a hypothesis. The preliminary report will also support the development of communication skills, data analysis and discussion of findings in relation to the field of research. The dissertation will be marked by 2 markers (one from UoL [supervisor] and the other from XJTLU). Oral presentations will be carried out in a hybrid format and will be marked by 3-4 markers.

The oral presentation reflects real-life situations (authentic assessment hallmark, Liverpool Curriculum Framework) for a research scientist and will be assessed by the panel on scientific correctness, presentation skills, time management and ability to answer questions. The assessments aim to support scientific and lay communication skills development, reflection on the project and self-confidence. In order to minimise the impact of air travel on climate change many conferences, poster and oral presentations are now taking place online or in a hybrid model e.g. with invited international attendees presenting via live video communication links. We will ensure that a hybrid model is possible with the option to change to completely online when necessary.

Re-sits are only available for the dissertation (resubmission) and not for the other components (see details below).

The break-down of the summative coursework assessments are as follows:

1)Literature Survey and project plan (15% final mark), testing LO’s 1, 2, and 3 with no resit.

2)Log Book (5% final mark), testing LO 4, with no resit.

3)Oral Presentation (15% final mark), testing LO’s 1, 2, and 5 with no resit.

4)Dissertation (65% final mark), testing LO’s 1, 2, 3, 4, and 6 with a resit opportunity.

Marks for components where no resit opportunities are offered will be carried forward, whether or not they are passed or failed, and will be calculated, with the same weighting, in the final module mark.
The dissertation resit is an independent assessment covering the same learning outcomes, in the same assessment type and bearing the same weighting with the original assessment.


Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcomeDeliveries 
 LO1 Critically evaluate relevant scientific literature and relate and combine it with the arguments, criteria, justifications and/or discussions of the project 
 LO2 Plan a piece of scientific research to formulate, evaluate or criticise a hypothesis and propose and formulate a set of experiments to test, challenge or defend this hypothesis, within a specified timeframe. 
 LO3 Consider, formulate and apply research ethics and health and safety regulations to prioritize, arrange and organize research work 
 LO4 Work independently in the lab with the essential technical skills acquired in a professional manner; maintaining an accurate and authentic record of methods and experimental findings 
 LO5 Effectively communicate and present their work to a scientific audience in the form of an oral and poster presentations 
 LO6 Write a final project report in the format of a dissertation to evaluate, contrast and discuss, the experimental outcomes of the research project and their scientific implications and significance

 S5 Plan research within ethical, health and safety, and research governance frameworks.

Rationale
This module is being created in order to facilitate XJTLU Pharmaceutical Sciences MRes Students to visit Liverpool to undertake their project. The overall module APH425 will continue to be managed at XJTLU, but the students will join Liverpool to use our facilities and gain additional benefits of studying abroad.

Admin

Marked for Rollover
No
Replace Future Instances
No
Replace Instances with Code
BIOS799
Notes
This is a new module designed for the students who enrol for MRes in Pharmaceutical Sciences in the XJTLU. This new module will be optional for year 2 for XJTLU students to undertake their research project in the University of Liverpool. XJTLU students who select this module will arrive in UoL to undertake their research project in UoL laboratories under the supervision of a UoL academic supervisor. Following their laboratory studies in the UoL, students will return to the XJTLU campus end of April for write-up of the dissertation and assessments will be undertaken at XJTLU.

Overview

Overview
The MRes in Pharmaceutical Sciences APH425 Study Abroad (Liverpool) module aims to provide XJTLU students with high level research training within the Institute of Systems, Molecular and Integrative Medicine (ISMIB) Schools and research departments contributing to the MRes in Pharmaceutical Sciences programme run by XJTLU. This module will be an optional module available to Y2 students undertaking the MRes in Pharmaceutical Sciences programme at the XJTLU and enable them to undertake their research project in the University of Liverpool. The module represents 120 credits, but is classed as 0 for UoL purposes because this is assessed by XJTLU.

Our aim is to develop research knowledge, skills and attributes including confidence and expertise, to contribute to the pursuit of further study or undertake roles in academia, the health sector and industry/education/service sectors in general. The module is suitable for bioscience graduates, and science graduates interested in training in biomedical sciences.

Students will join a UoL research group and take advantage of relevant first-class facilities and an active research environment at the University of Liverpool. This module is designed to provide a clear progression of research education.

Students will join Liverpool for a proportion of the APH425 module, a 120-credit (XJTLU) module that gives authentic and hands-on research experience. Students focus on a dedicated research project, which includes preparing a preliminary report; preparing a project plan and undertaking original research using experimental/data handling techniques learned; writing up a dissertation in the style of a paper in a scientific journal and preparing an oral presentation to discuss their project, together with continual assessment of the student’s performance (Hallmarks of Liverpool Curriculum Framework). The teaching approach relies upon research-led and enquiry-based learning with authentic assessments in the form of a preliminary project proposal, oral presentation, scientific report, and continual assessment of the student’s performance (Hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

The teaching delivery is based on the research supervisor model used for postgraduate research degrees. Students will be provided with training in relevant research techniques required for their own project, but will subsequently develop the ability to work independently on their own project. Generic guidance on preparation of the written report and oral presentation will be given and supplemented by project-specific guidance provided by the project supervisor. Write-up of the dissertation will take place following the return of students to the XJTLU campus and the assessment of the module is undertaken at XJTLU via the preliminary project proposal, oral presentation and project report along with continual assessment of the student's performance.

Students will normally choose their project from a list provided on receipt of their offer, but it is possible for them to work with the Module Organiser to find a potential supervisor and develop a project more aligned to their own interests if a suitable project has not been provided. Projects address research areas that reflect the strengths of ISMIB and covers a wide range of formats including (but not limited to) bioinformatics, clinical studies, animal studies, cell and tissue culture, systematic reviews and meta-analyses, computer modelling. The supervisor is responsible for supporting the development of the technical and analytical skills needed for the project. Direction of the project should be primarily student-led enquiry with support from the supervisor and their team, where appropriate. The purpose of this approach is to facilitate the development of problem- solving skills; critical thinking; scientific creativity; an ability to apply appropriate experimental design and analysis and the skills to communicate findings and ideas to a wide audience. This approach is consistent with the Liverpool Hallmarks of research-connected teaching and active learning as set out in the Liverpool Curriculum Framework.
Educational Aims
1.To provide students with an opportunity to conduct in-depth, cutting-edge, independent research on a defined topic under supervision of a qualified member of academic staff within an active, first-class research environment.

2.To give students a holistic training in practical research and make an original and significant contribution to knowledge in the specific field of study.

3.To enable students to gain a comprehensive understanding of the techniques applicable to research or advanced scholarship.

4.To facilitate the developments of project management skills, report writing skills, presentation skills, time management skills for research or investigative work in their professional careers.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Not Required as it is not marketed outside (only limited to XJTLU)
Outline Syllabus
All students are provided with a list of research projects which are related to the research currently undertaken by ISMIB academic staff. Students are free to make their choice according to their specific needs or interest.

In general, students are required to perform the following tasks within this module:

• Gain knowledge of lab safety and the principles of research ethics
• Complete a risk assessment for their research project
• Perform literature survey of their chosen research area and keep information updated
• Submit a literature survey report
• Submit a proposed project plan detailing the research activities (to be approved by supervisor)
• Perform research activity according to the agreed plan
• Produce a poster to present their research project.
• Perform oral presentation of their poster
• Submit a progress research reports at the end of Semester 2
• Deliver a power point presentation of research outcome
• Submit a final thesis
Teaching and Learning Methods
This module involves tutorials to help students gain knowledge of lab safety, principles of research ethics, literature survey, presentation, report writing, project planning, etc. Students are required to attend departmental seminars to increase their general knowledge. Specific technical training will be given by supervisor and technical supporting staffs. We will also provide pastoral support to the students during their time in Liverpool.

Students have to choose a specified research project and submit a preliminary report, describing the relevant background information, the hypothesis to be tested (where relevant), a plan of work and an anticipated timetable.

Students will undertake the research projects in two semesters. The results arising from the research will be subsequently reported by oral presentation and a research paper/dissertation. Timely, relevant and specific, constructive and actionable feedback will be provided to students in-class, on-paper and/or in-person on for each assignment.

The students on the programme come from a wide background. During their time spent in Liverpool, discussion between students and their research colleagues, from these diverse backgrounds affords the students a rich opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this multinational community fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their internationalised perspective (Global citizenship, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching and learning may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
All students plan a dedicated empirical research project, the content of which is directed by the academic supervisor of the project.

The module is assessed by XJTLU via submission of a preliminary literature survey report and project plan, an oral presentation to peers and academic members, submission of dissertation and continual assessment (See detailed assessment plan given under 'Assessments' tab). Written assessments are submitted and marked online for all students including a draft formative opportunity.
The continual assessment element will assess the student’s conduct and performance throughout the project and will be conducted by the Liverpool Supervisor.

The preliminary project report will not be marked anonymously as it will need to be marked by the UoL supervisor, an expert on the research topic and so the student will be easily identified. The reports reflect real-life scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark, Liverpool Curriculum Framework). The preliminary report will be a literature survey of the research area suggested, critical analysis of the literature, and would include a hypothesis. The preliminary report will also support the development of communication skills, data analysis and discussion of findings in relation to the field of research. The dissertation will be marked by 2 markers (one from UoL [supervisor] and the other from XJTLU). Oral presentations will be carried out in a hybrid format and will be marked by 3-4 markers.

The oral presentation reflects real-life situations (authentic assessment hallmark, Liverpool Curriculum Framework) for a research scientist and will be assessed by the panel on scientific correctness, presentation skills, time management and ability to answer questions. The assessments aim to support scientific and lay communication skills development, reflection on the project and self-confidence. In order to minimise the impact of air travel on climate change many conferences, poster and oral presentations are now taking place online or in a hybrid model e.g. with invited international attendees presenting via live video communication links. We will ensure that a hybrid model is possible with the option to change to completely online when necessary.

Re-sits are only available for the dissertation (resubmission) and not for the other components (see details below).

The break-down of the summative coursework assessments are as follows:

1)Literature Survey and project plan (15% final mark), testing LO’s 1, 2, and 3 with no resit.

2)Log Book (5% final mark), testing LO 4, with no resit.

3)Oral Presentation (15% final mark), testing LO’s 1, 2, and 5 with no resit.

4)Dissertation (65% final mark), testing LO’s 1, 2, 3, 4, and 6 with a resit opportunity.

Marks for components where no resit opportunities are offered will be carried forward, whether or not they are passed or failed, and will be calculated, with the same weighting, in the final module mark.
The dissertation resit is an independent assessment covering the same learning outcomes, in the same assessment type and bearing the same weighting with the original assessment.


Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcomeDeliveries 
 LO1 Critically evaluate relevant scientific literature and relate and combine it with the arguments, criteria, justifications and/or discussions of the project 
 LO2 Plan a piece of scientific research to formulate, evaluate or criticise a hypothesis and propose and formulate a set of experiments to test, challenge or defend this hypothesis, within a specified timeframe. 
 LO3 Consider, formulate and apply research ethics and health and safety regulations to prioritize, arrange and organize research work 
 LO4 Work independently in the lab with the essential technical skills acquired in a professional manner; maintaining an accurate and authentic record of methods and experimental findings 
 LO5 Effectively communicate and present their work to a scientific audience in the form of an oral and poster presentations 
 LO6 Write a final project report in the format of a dissertation to evaluate, contrast and discuss, the experimental outcomes of the research project and their scientific implications and significance 
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcomeDeliveries 
 S1 Literacy ability to produce clear, structured written work and oral literacy - including listening and questioning 
 S2 Problem solving/ critical thinking/ creativity analysing facts and situations and applying creative thinking to develop appropriate solutions. 
 S3 Communication, listening and questioning respecting others, contributing to discussions, influencing, presentations. 
 S4 Self-management readiness to accept responsibility (i.e. leadership), flexibility, resilience, self-starting, initiative, integrity, willingness to take risks, appropriate assertiveness, time management, readiness to improve own performance based on feedback/reflective learning. 
 S5 Plan research within ethical, health and safety, and research governance frameworks. 


Overview

Requirements Overview
Companion study abroad research project module to XJTLU MRes Pharmaceutical Sciences module (APH425).

Students will complete their lab work in Liverpool and return to china to complete their write up. The project will be formally assessed by XJTLU.

Rationale
This module is being created in order to facilitate XJTLU Pharmaceutical Sciences MRes Students to visit Liverpool to undertake their project. The overall module APH425 will continue to be managed at XJTLU, but the students will join Liverpool to use our facilities and gain additional benefits of studying abroad.

Replace Instances with Code
BIOS799
Notes
This is a new module designed for the students who enrol for MRes in Pharmaceutical Sciences in the XJTLU. This new module will be optional for year 2 for XJTLU students to undertake their research project in the University of Liverpool. XJTLU students who select this module will arrive in UoL to undertake their research project in UoL laboratories under the supervision of a UoL academic supervisor. Following their laboratory studies in the UoL, students will return to the XJTLU campus end of April for write-up of the dissertation and assessments will be undertaken at XJTLU.

Overview

Overview
The MRes in Pharmaceutical Sciences APH425 Study Abroad (Liverpool) module aims to provide XJTLU students with high level research training within the Institute of Systems, Molecular and Integrative Medicine (ISMIB) Schools and research departments contributing to the MRes in Pharmaceutical Sciences programme run by XJTLU. This module will be an optional module available to Y2 students undertaking the MRes in Pharmaceutical Sciences programme at the XJTLU and enable them to undertake their research project in the University of Liverpool. The module represents 120 credits, but is classed as 0 for UoL purposes because this is assessed by XJTLU.

Our aim is to develop research knowledge, skills and attributes including confidence and expertise, to contribute to the pursuit of further study or undertake roles in academia, the health sector and industry/education/service sectors in general. The module is suitable for bioscience graduates, and science graduates interested in training in biomedical sciences.

Students will join a UoL research group and take advantage of relevant first-class facilities and an active research environment at the University of Liverpool. This module is designed to provide a clear progression of research education.

Students will join Liverpool for a proportion of the APH425 module, a 120-credit (XJTLU) module that gives authentic and hands-on research experience. Students focus on a dedicated research project, which includes preparing a preliminary report; preparing a project plan and undertaking original research using experimental/data handling techniques learned; writing up a dissertation in the style of a paper in a scientific journal and preparing an oral presentation to discuss their project, together with continual assessment of the student’s performance (Hallmarks of Liverpool Curriculum Framework). The teaching approach relies upon research-led and enquiry-based learning with authentic assessments in the form of a preliminary project proposal, oral presentation, scientific report, and continual assessment of the student’s performance (Hallmarks of the Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

The teaching delivery is based on the research supervisor model used for postgraduate research degrees. Students will be provided with training in relevant research techniques required for their own project, but will subsequently develop the ability to work independently on their own project. Generic guidance on preparation of the written report and oral presentation will be given and supplemented by project-specific guidance provided by the project supervisor. Write-up of the dissertation will take place following the return of students to the XJTLU campus and the assessment of the module is undertaken at XJTLU via the preliminary project proposal, oral presentation and project report along with continual assessment of the student's performance.

Students will normally choose their project from a list provided on receipt of their offer, but it is possible for them to work with the Module Organiser to find a potential supervisor and develop a project more aligned to their own interests if a suitable project has not been provided. Projects address research areas that reflect the strengths of ISMIB and covers a wide range of formats including (but not limited to) bioinformatics, clinical studies, animal studies, cell and tissue culture, systematic reviews and meta-analyses, computer modelling. The supervisor is responsible for supporting the development of the technical and analytical skills needed for the project. Direction of the project should be primarily student-led enquiry with support from the supervisor and their team, where appropriate. The purpose of this approach is to facilitate the development of problem- solving skills; critical thinking; scientific creativity; an ability to apply appropriate experimental design and analysis and the skills to communicate findings and ideas to a wide audience. This approach is consistent with the Liverpool Hallmarks of research-connected teaching and active learning as set out in the Liverpool Curriculum Framework.
Educational Aims
1.To provide students with an opportunity to conduct in-depth, cutting-edge, independent research on a defined topic under supervision of a qualified member of academic staff within an active, first-class research environment.

2.To give students a holistic training in practical research and make an original and significant contribution to knowledge in the specific field of study.

3.To enable students to gain a comprehensive understanding of the techniques applicable to research or advanced scholarship.

4.To facilitate the developments of project management skills, report writing skills, presentation skills, time management skills for research or investigative work in their professional careers.
Marketing Module Synopsis
Not Required as it is not marketed outside (only limited to XJTLU)
Outline Syllabus
All students are provided with a list of research projects which are related to the research currently undertaken by ISMIB academic staff. Students are free to make their choice according to their specific needs or interest.

In general, students are required to perform the following tasks within this module:

• Gain knowledge of lab safety and the principles of research ethics
• Complete a risk assessment for their research project
• Perform literature survey of their chosen research area and keep information updated
• Submit a literature survey report
• Submit a proposed project plan detailing the research activities (to be approved by supervisor)
• Perform research activity according to the agreed plan
• Produce a poster to present their research project.
• Perform oral presentation of their poster
• Submit a progress research reports at the end of Semester 2
• Deliver a power point presentation of research outcome
• Submit a final thesis
Teaching and Learning Methods
This module involves tutorials to help students gain knowledge of lab safety, principles of research ethics, literature survey, presentation, report writing, project planning, etc. Students are required to attend departmental seminars to increase their general knowledge. Specific technical training will be given by supervisor and technical supporting staffs. We will also provide pastoral support to the students during their time in Liverpool.

Students have to choose a specified research project and submit a preliminary report, describing the relevant background information, the hypothesis to be tested (where relevant), a plan of work and an anticipated timetable.

Students will undertake the research projects in two semesters. The results arising from the research will be subsequently reported by oral presentation and a research paper/dissertation. Timely, relevant and specific, constructive and actionable feedback will be provided to students in-class, on-paper and/or in-person on for each assignment.

The students on the programme come from a wide background. During their time spent in Liverpool, discussion between students and their research colleagues, from these diverse backgrounds affords the students a rich opportunity to experience and understand cultures other than their own. The formation of this multinational community fosters the values of respect and equality amongst the students and improves their internationalised perspective (Global citizenship, Liverpool Curriculum Framework).

Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for teaching and learning may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.
Assessment Strategy
All students plan a dedicated empirical research project, the content of which is directed by the academic supervisor of the project.

The module is assessed by XJTLU via submission of a preliminary literature survey report and project plan, an oral presentation to peers and academic members, submission of dissertation and continual assessment (See detailed assessment plan given under 'Assessments' tab). Written assessments are submitted and marked online for all students including a draft formative opportunity.
The continual assessment element will assess the student’s conduct and performance throughout the project and will be conducted by the Liverpool Supervisor.

The preliminary project report will not be marked anonymously as it will need to be marked by the UoL supervisor, an expert on the research topic and so the student will be easily identified. The reports reflect real-life scenarios (Authentic assessment hallmark, Liverpool Curriculum Framework). The preliminary report will be a literature survey of the research area suggested, critical analysis of the literature, and would include a hypothesis. The preliminary report will also support the development of communication skills, data analysis and discussion of findings in relation to the field of research. The dissertation will be marked by 2 markers (one from UoL [supervisor] and the other from XJTLU). Oral presentations will be carried out in a hybrid format and will be marked by 3-4 markers.

The oral presentation reflects real-life situations (authentic assessment hallmark, Liverpool Curriculum Framework) for a research scientist and will be assessed by the panel on scientific correctness, presentation skills, time management and ability to answer questions. The assessments aim to support scientific and lay communication skills development, reflection on the project and self-confidence. In order to minimise the impact of air travel on climate change many conferences, poster and oral presentations are now taking place online or in a hybrid model e.g. with invited international attendees presenting via live video communication links. We will ensure that a hybrid model is possible with the option to change to completely online when necessary.

Re-sits are only available for the dissertation (resubmission) and not for the other components (see details below).

The break-down of the summative coursework assessments are as follows:

1)Literature Survey and project plan (15% final mark), testing LO’s 1, 2, and 3 with no resit.

2)Log Book (5% final mark), testing LO 4, with no resit.

3)Oral Presentation (15% final mark), testing LO’s 1, 2, and 5 with no resit.

4)Dissertation (65% final mark), testing LO’s 1, 2, 3, 4, and 6 with a resit opportunity.

Marks for components where no resit opportunities are offered will be carried forward, whether or not they are passed or failed, and will be calculated, with the same weighting, in the final module mark.
The dissertation resit is an independent assessment covering the same learning outcomes, in the same assessment type and bearing the same weighting with the original assessment.


Students will be informed that, in exceptional circumstances (e.g. global pandemics), plans for assessment may be subject to change. Contact will be made via the VLE and an e-mail will be sent to each of the students informing them of any changes that prove to be necessary. The Health and Life Sciences FAQSC will be informed in advance of any such changes, so that approval can be given.

Outcomes

Learning Outcomes
 ReferenceOutcomeDeliveries 
 LO1 Critically evaluate relevant scientific literature and relate and combine it with the arguments, criteria, justifications and/or discussions of the project 
 LO2 Plan a piece of scientific research to formulate, evaluate or criticise a hypothesis and propose and formulate a set of experiments to test, challenge or defend this hypothesis, within a specified timeframe. 
 LO3 Consider, formulate and apply research ethics and health and safety regulations to prioritize, arrange and organize research work 
 LO4 Work independently in the lab with the essential technical skills acquired in a professional manner; maintaining an accurate and authentic record of methods and experimental findings 
 LO5 Effectively communicate and present their work to a scientific audience in the form of an oral and poster presentations 
 LO6 Write a final project report in the format of a dissertation to evaluate, contrast and discuss, the experimental outcomes of the research project and their scientific implications and significance 
Skills

Skills

 ReferenceOutcomeDeliveries 
 S1 Literacy ability to produce clear, structured written work and oral literacy - including listening and questioning 
 S2 Problem solving/ critical thinking/ creativity analysing facts and situations and applying creative thinking to develop appropriate solutions. 
 S3 Communication, listening and questioning respecting others, contributing to discussions, influencing, presentations. 
 S4 Self-management readiness to accept responsibility (i.e. leadership), flexibility, resilience, self-starting, initiative, integrity, willingness to take risks, appropriate assertiveness, time management, readiness to improve own performance based on feedback/reflective learning. 
 S5 Plan research within ethical, health and safety, and research governance frameworks. 


Overview

Requirements Overview
Companion study abroad research project module to XJTLU MRes Pharmaceutical Sciences module (APH425).

Students will complete their lab work in Liverpool and return to china to complete their write up. The project will be formally assessed by XJTLU.
